characters: BLACKNESS OF THE PITCH FILLS THE SCREEN. TITLES BEGIN.
AS THE CAULDRON TIPS, THE CAMERA PUSHES INSIDE, THE
THE COAL CHUTE ON THE SIDE OF THE HOUSE --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A GROUP OF CAROLERS, their eager faces upturned, SINGS an endless and cloying roundelay of "Little Drummer Boy." They sing with self-righteous good cheer. As they pompously begin their umpteenth verse, THE CAMERA SLOWLY PANS UP THE ADDAMS MANSION -- past the black wreath on the front door, past broken windows, weather-beaten shingles, a creaking shutter.

dialogues.speaker: THE ROOF
dialogues.text: where the Addams Family members, GOMEZ, MORTICIA, GRANNY, PUGSLEY, WEDNESDAY, and LURCH, their faithful butler, gleefully POUR a CAULDRON OF BUBBLING, STEAMING PITCH over the edge.

dialogues.speaker: C.U. AN OVER-SIZED "CUCKOO" CLOCK --
dialogues.text: The clock is a perfect REPLICA OF THE ADDAMS FAMILY HOUSE, down to the creaking shutter. It chimes the hour. In ONE WINDOW, a LITTLE MECHANICAL GOMEZ bends a MECHANICAL MORTICIA back until she's almost off her feet and plants a kiss between her clockwork decolletage. One, two, three mechanical kisses, counting toward seven o'clock. IN ANOTHER WINDOW, A MECHANICAL PUGSLEY hangs a MECHANICAL WEDNESDAY from a noose on a gallows, up and down. Meanwhile, little BURSTS OF FOG float off the rooftop where a little MECHANICAL GRANNY cranks her fog machine. The front door of the house pops open, and a MECHANICAL LURCH appears and begins sweeping. Just then, THING, the disembodied hand with the full-bodied personality, CLIMBS into view over the back of the clock. Thing leaps to the floor and SCAMPERS down the hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: follows Thing along the hallway.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He runs past a couple of doors, past a pair of LEGS in pajamas, feet in bedroom slippers. He skids to a halt and BACK TRACKS to the legs. He pulls on the cuff of the pajama bottoms. They belong to GOMEZ, who stands in the doorway to

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gomez wears a fez and a smoking jacket over his pajamas. Even at this early hour, he puffs on his trademark cigar. Gomez is all enthusiasm or all despair. At the moment, he radiates unfathomable woe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Think of it, Thing. He's been gone for twenty-five years. For twenty- five years we've attempted to contact Fester in the great beyond... The room is a dusty, cobweb-filled, long-unoccupied shrin to Gomez's lost brother, Fester. Gomez drifts in from the doorway. The room has remained untouched since Fester's disappearance as a teenager. The thick coating of dust and cobwebs adorns the mementoes of a rapscallion's youth - a football pennant from Alcatraz, headless sports trophies, a high school photo with all the other students keeping as much distance from Fester as possible. As he lovingly and morosely surveys the room:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... And for twenty-five years, nothing. Not a whisper, not a clue. I'm beginning to think my my brother truly is lost. Gomez sighs.   Thing TUGS at his cuff, pulling him toward the

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Galloping ahead of Gomez, Thing leaps onto an old-fashioned door latch and the door swings open INTO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gomez approaches the bed.   Asleep on scarlet satin sheet is...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gazing at Morticia)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at her -- I would die for her. I would kill for her. Either way -- what bliss. Low-voiced, incisive, and subtle, with Morticia, smiles are rare. The ghostly whiteness of her complexion is offset by the red of the pillowcase upon which her hair is spread like a diabolic halo. A dark Garbo, sultry and remote, she's a ruined beauty. Morticia OPENS HER EYES.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (adoringly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Unhappy, darling?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (passionately)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yes, yes. Completely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pugsley crouches on the floor, playing with his kid-sized chemistry set. The walls of his room are covered with road signs he's collected -- "Bridge Out!", "Detour! Excavation Ahead!", "Dangerous Undertow!", "Keep Clear! High Voltage!" SAWED-OFF STOP SIGNS, still on their poles, are stacked in the corner. In another corner stands a CYLINDRICAL FLOOR-TO-CEILING FISH TANK, FILLED WITH PIRANHA. This tubby energetic monster of a nine-year-old boy has every chance of growing up to be the public monster his parents would be proud of. He MIXES chemicals in a beaker. The brew steams.    Grin- ning wickedly, Pugsley SWALLOWS it down. He contorts, undergoing the beginnings of a transforma- tion, then SHRINKS to the size of a mouse. Laughing, he crawls out of his human-size pajamas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Solemn and mournful, ten-year-old Wednesday has black hair and white skin like her mother. She sits on a stool among the stored Addams' family objects, ONE END OF A STRING TIED TO HER TOOTH, THE OTHER TIED TO A TRAP DOOR. The trap door is flung open, GRANNY pokes her head through. She's a giggly hag who looks like she was in the bathtub when the hairdryer fell in. Wednesday's pulled tooth swings at the end of the string.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Grandmama. In a foul mood, Granny tromps up into the attic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You kids are going to have to kill your own breakfast this morning. Wednesday opens a cigar box. Inside the box are assorted human and animal teeth, fangs and dentures, along with a collection of glass eyes. Wednesday drops her tooth in the box.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gomez takes Morticia in his arms. As she languidly drapes herself across his chest, she is caught in a sudden shaft of sunlight. She squints. On the bedside table beside her, Morticia's OVERSIZED CARNIVOROUS ORCHID WILTS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gomez... the sun... il me perce comme un poignard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (wildly aroused)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tish... that's French!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nonchalant)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oui.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cara mia!

dialogues.speaker: A6 CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He kisses his way up to her neck, then, suddenly bursting with enthusiasm and a sense of purpose, LEAPS from the bed, drawing his bedside saber from its sheath and BRANDISHING it at the offending beam.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: En garde monsieur sole! He thrusts and parries, pantomiming a duel with the shaft of light.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gomez?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Querida?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Last night, you were... unhinged. You were like some desperate, howling demon. You frightened me. Do it again. Gomez, instantly aflame.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Granny delivers a swift kick to her fog machine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lousy bucket of bolts...! The FOG MACHINE, straight out of a Jules Verne nightmare, is malfunctioning this morning, struggling to churn out its patches of fog.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the window, Gomez pokes his head out. In the background, Morticia brushes her hair with a silver filigree brush.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (disturbed)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Granny - where's your fog?

dialogues.speaker: FROM ABOVE
dialogues.text: the fog machine hurtles downwards, missing decapitating Gomez by millimeters. It crashes below, smashing through the front porch roof.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Standing beside the front door is LURCH, the gigantic family butler, a reanimated stitched-together behemoth. He holds two brown paper lunch bags in his enormous hands. The bags' contents wriggle, eager to escape.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (taking her bag)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Lurch.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Pugsley takes his bag, opens it, and peers inside.    Lur GROWLS, and Pugsley closes the bag.

dialogues.speaker: SAME TIME
dialogues.text: Gomez is HITTING GOLF BALLS -- Thing serving as his tee -- while Morticia sips tea.

dialogues.speaker: ONE OF THE GOLF BALLS
dialogues.text: flies with incredible speed THROUGH THE WINDOW of the ADDAMS' ONLY NEIGHBOR. This well-tended HOME sits on the hill overlooking the Addams' Mansion like some Republican sentinel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JUDGE WOMACK, the Addams' CRUSTY PATRICIAN NEIGHBOR, is having his breakfast when Gomez's golf ball lands in his cornflakes, shattering the bowl, covering him with milk. Judge Womack hurries to his broken window, shaking his fist:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damn you, Addams!

dialogues.speaker: FROM THEIR VANTAGE POINT --
dialogues.text: it appears to Gomez and Morticia that Judge Womack is waving to them. Gomez waves back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calls)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry about the window, Judge! Keep the ball! I have a whole bucketful. He holds up a bucket of golf balls. He tosses his golfclub to Thing, who DEPOSITS IT in the golfbag.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Gomez joins Morticia watching THE DEPARTING SCHOOL BUS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The little ones, off to school. Bless them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They grow up so fast, don't they?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Too fast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tires smoking, the school bus strains to chug down the road. Gleefully hanging from the rear bumper is Pugsley, dragging his heels.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morticia, wearing gardening gloves, is snipping the blossoms off her roses. Gomez sits at a table, playing CHESS with Thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a milestone, Tish. This very evening -- our twenty-fifth seance. All those years, gnawed by guilt, undone by woe, burning with uncertainty...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (yearningly) Oh Gomez, don't torture yourself. That's my job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (lustfully) Tish...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Imagine, Darling, if Fester did come back. Half-alive, barely human, a rotting shell...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't tease.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TULLY ALFORD, the family attorney, and his wife, MARGARET approach "GATE," a wrought-iron monstrosity that opens of its own accord. Though Tully comes here often and Margaret has been here before, they never cease to be startled by "Gate." Tully has a puffy, once handsome face, and an embittered grey aura that is the mark of a middle-age misspent. High-strung and superficial, Margaret is more disap- pointed in Tully than he is in himself. Margaret passes through Gate first. Then, as Tully passes through, Gate slams on him, clipping him and catching the end of his coat. Tully fights Gate for his coat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me go! Ignoring Tully, Margaret continues stiffly up the walk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Gate)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gimme that! Stop it! I'm warning you! It's not a good day!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gomez moves a chess piece. Thing gestures out the window. Gomez and Morticia both look out. As they do, Thing moves two chess pieces, cheating.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking out)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tully is here, darling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sing. Dance. Date.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (coming to his senses)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mother, I'm... I'm so terribly sorry... (he kneels at her side)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was just a party. It's over. It means nothing. Those Siamese twins, that hunchback, Cousin It - they're not you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (clutching him savagely)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say it, Gordon. Make me believe it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love you.   And I want money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (very no-nonsense)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've got to find Tully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morticia is looking for her children. She discovers Pugsley ASLEEP, curled up on the SILVER PLATTER WHERE THE TWO-HEADED PIG LAY. She finds this enchanting. Gomez enters.   Morticia shushes him; she points to the platter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispering)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look - our little boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispering)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All tuckered out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispering)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So sweet. He looks just... like a little entree. Pugsley wakes up; he looks around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sleepy)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where... where's the party?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's over, darling - have you seen your sister?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not since before the Mamushka.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gomez?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't fret - we'll find her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gomez rallies the family for the search. Morticia wears a black cloak. Granny has grabbed her divining rod. Lurch distributes torches, then stands aside, awaiting instructions. Pugsley helps Gomez unroll an ancient map of the area.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fan out. Pugsley - head for the dung heap. Mama and Morticia - the shallow graves. I'll take the abyss, and Lurch - check the bottomless pit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (worried)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her favorite...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calls out)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fester!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Up here. They look up at Fester, looking down at them from Wednesday's window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fester! You take the ravine!     And the unmarked, abandoned well!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somebody should stay behind - in case she comes back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good man!   Good thinking!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then who'll take the swamp?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thing tugs at the cuff of Gomez's pants.       Gomez nods

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the spirit, Thing - lend a hand! Let's go!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They all sweep off, with Gomez in the lead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fester is still at the window.      Abigail joins him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Spread far and wide over the grounds, the various members of the family search for Wednesday, tiny lights aloft, calling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where the hell is Tully?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They head out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fester and Virginia find...

dialogues.speaker: TULLY -
dialogues.text: sitting in an armchair, basking in the rays of sunshine that beam from a copy of "The Sun Also Rises." Tully smiles at them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Relaxing.   Taking a little sun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you gone mad?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Au contraire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tully closes the book and smugly unfurls a LEGAL DOCUMENT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thing hops lily pads, stopping occasionally to quest the air for his mistress.

dialogues.speaker: THE NIGHT
dialogues.text: Torch aloft, Pugsley searches through the primeval forest

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lurch picks up a car -- looking for Wednesday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morticia and Granny stand in the middle of the dripping dankness. Stalagmites. Stalactites. Granny's torch casts scary shadows on the cave walls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling out)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wednesday! Wednesday!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Mama, I was sure we'd find her here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gomez reaches a stately mausoleum at the far end of the cemetery. Two proud marble vultures guard the entryway. Gomez lowers the uplifted claw of one of the vultures and the stone doors slide open. He steps into -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inside it is catacomb-like, filled with the bleached bones of the Addams dead. Gomez's torch casts shadows -- one of which belongs to Wednesday, curled asleep on a stone sarcophagus. Relieved to find her, Gomez approaches quietly. He doesn't want to wake her up. He lifts her tenderly in his arms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gate can't open. He rattles miserably on his hinges -- locked tight with heavy chains and yellow police tape - large "NO TRESPASSING!! COURT ORDER!! ADDAMS FAMILY - KEEP OUT!!" signs are posted on Gate's rusty bars.

dialogues.speaker: PULL BACK TO REVEAL --
dialogues.text: the family, appalled at the sight of Gate.    Lurch carri the sleeping Wednesday and Pugsley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's all this?

dialogues.speaker: TULLY --
dialogues.text: hurries down the walkway, waving his legal document.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is a restraining order, Gomez.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A restraining order?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It requires you to keep a distance of one thousand yards from this house. You've got about nine hundred and ninety-nine yards to go - catch my drift?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in disbelief)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am restrained - from my own house!?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not your house, moustache! Not any more! It belongs to the eldest living descendant, the older of the brothers -- Fester Addams!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But - this is lunacy!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fester adores Gomez!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's afraid of him. Seeing the twins brought it all back. (to Gomez)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're bitter rivals, Gomez - always were, always will be!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not so! Those girls meant nothing - he knows that! I demand to see Fester!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry - no can do. He's very hurt - it's not a good time. Leave it alone. Or better yet - just leave.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Wednesday comes forward, rubbing the sleep from her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But he isn't even Uncle Fester. Gomez and Morticia turn to look at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to his family)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do not fear - justic shall prevail. The courts will decide! (fervently)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They say a man who represents himself has a fool for a client. Well, with God as my witness - I am that fool!

dialogues.speaker: C.U. GAVEL --
dialogues.text: hammers on the Judge's bench. PULL BACK to reveal --

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE WOMACK
dialogues.text: is the presiding judge.   He hammers the bench again, the reads his decision.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Given applicable standards of proof, the attempts to impugn this man's character or question his identity have been woefully inadequate. It is with no small amount of personal satisfaction that I declare Fester Addams legal executor of the Addams estate and rightful owner of all properties and possessions contained herein. Gomez Addams... (He holds up a golf ball)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I believe this is yours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The family members TROOP to the car with their few possessions.

dialogues.speaker: GOMEZ
dialogues.text: already sits in the passenger seat of the Duesenberg, his coat draped over his shoulders as if he were an invalid, his head thrown back. Morticia carries out Cleo, her carnivorous plant. Granny carries her favorite cauldron, Wednesday one of her Marie Antoinette dolls, Pugsley his chemistry set. Lurch uproot his favorite tree and joins the procession. Thing follows dragging a toy wagon packed with his rings, his glove.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Duesenberg eases out of the driveway and onto the street, WEIGHED DOWN by Lurch's tree, sticking out of the trunk.

dialogues.speaker: FESTER
dialogues.text: standing at a second story window, watches the car drive off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A two-story NEON ARROW points the way to this bungalow court -- Bright and awful ersatz western. LOG CABINS OF SIMULATED WOOD surround the TEEPEE-SHAPED OFFICE. The Addams' Duesenberg is parked in front of the furthest cabin. The asphalt has been ripped up in big chunks and Lurch's tree is parked next to the Addams' new home.

dialogues.speaker: C.U. DRESSING TABLE MIRROR
dialogues.text: Morticia leans into frame. With an icepick and a hammer, she deftly makes a large spidery CRACK in the round mirro Sighing deeply, she stands back to admire her handiwork. Granny joins her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I like it. Her mother pats her consolingly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just as long as we're together, n'est pas, mon cher? As she turns to Gomez, we see the interior of the bungalo -- all ersatz cowboy and Indian mixed with chrome-plated plastic and orange shag carpet.

dialogues.speaker: GOMEZ
dialogues.text: sits slumped in a   chair made from wagon wheel and nauga hyde. It's as if    all of his insane, vibrant energy has been leeched from   him. He's a broken man. He looks back at her as if he's   never heard French.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh? Wednesday tends to him.    She and her mother exchange a worried look.

dialogues.speaker: PUGSLEY
dialogues.text: comes from the bathroom, nibbling a wrapped bar of motel soap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This place isn't so bad. They even put candy in the bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the soap, dear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. He takes another greedy bite. Wednesday pats her father's arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you want a cigar, Father?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in a monotone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're very bad for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (very worried)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Father? Wednesday exchanges a panic-stricken look with Morticia. The family moves closer to Gomez.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But maybe I'll have one of those... He takes a bar of soap from Pugsley.     Gomez unwraps it and morosely eats.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C.U. on three hands, as they reach up to pull three of the countless chains.

dialogues.speaker: THE COAL CHUTE ON THE SIDE OF THE HOUSE --
dialogues.text: drops open, dumping out Fester, Abigail, and Tully - all of them wet and bedraggled and gasping for air.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Fester)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're doing this on purpose.

dialogues.speaker: A133 CONTINUED
dialogues.text: They all struggle to their feet and march grimly back toward the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gomez is STRETCHED OUT on the naked box springs of his bed -- the mattress pushed aside. A damp cloth covers his eyes. Thing MASSAGES his aching head. A bowl of MOTEL SOAPS is beside him. In contrast, Morticia squarely faces the crisis. She addresses the family from the head of the breakfast table, the want ads open on the table before her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are Addamses, and we will not submit. Who recalls the fable of the tortoise and the hare? The swift, yet lazy little cottontail, and his slow but determined companion? What does that story teach us, as Addamses?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kill the hare. Skin it.   Boil it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Put the tortoise on the highway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: During rush hour.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes! We will survive! Poison us, strangle us, break our bones - we will come back for more. And why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because we like it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because we're Addamses! Gomez tries to rouse himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (out of it)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're Addamses... He burps -- soap bubbles floating from his mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wednesday and Pugsley have set up a LEMONADE STAND, their contribution to the Addams' financial well-being. An array of POISONS are lined up on their rickety table. They've slashed their prices to a nickel per cup. The pitcher on the table before them steams. Cars speed by. Carrying a SAMPLE VACUUM CLEANER and a bucket, Lurch come out of the motel courtyard. Pugsley offers him a cup of punch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here, Lurch.   On the house. Lurch downs it in a gulp and heads off. Feeling the effects of the lemonade, Lurch BURPS -- a tongue of flame shoots from his mouth and INCINERATES A WOODEN INDIAN advertising the Wampum Court.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morticia is being interviewed by a PERSONNEL OFFICER, a relentlessly perky gal with a clipboard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have so many homemakers re-entering the work force - your domestic skills can be very valuable. College?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Private tutors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Major?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Spells and Hexes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (knowingly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Liberal Arts. Have you been a volunteer, PTA, service organizations?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, one day each week I visit Death Row at our local prison, with my children.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (perplexed)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With your children?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Autographs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, what about your husband? Is he currently employed?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's... he's going through a bad patch at the moment. But it's not his fault.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with some bitterness)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course not. What is he - A loafer? A hopeless layabout? A shiftless dreamer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (wistfully)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not anymore. The Personnel Officer shoots Morticia a doubtful glance, and begins rifling through her card file.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Abigail and Fester are seated at opposite ends of the couch. Fester stares off into space. Abigail is going through a stack of colorful travel brochures.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Mediterranean, the Riviera - once we find the money, we'll go everywhere. We'll try again, right after lunch. Gordon - where should we go first?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sadly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Acapulco? Cancun? (she snaps her fingers in the air, castanet- style, trying to be festive)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ariba! Ariba!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You choose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wednesday and Pugsley are at their lemonade stand. They are negotiating with a PRISSY LITTLE GIRL IN A GIRL SCOUT UNIFORM. The girl scout carries several boxes of Girl Scout cookies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with grave doubts)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is this made from real lemons?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I only like all-natural foods and beverages. Organically grown, with no preservatives. Are you sure they're real lemons?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well... I   tell you what. I'll buy a cup, if   you buy a box of my delicious   girl scout cookies. Do we have a   deal?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are they made from real girl scouts?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: White clapboard. Geraniums in the flower boxes. Surrounded by a white picket fence. Carrying his SAMPLE VACUUM CLEANER AND BUCKET, the tools his new trade, Lurch carefully opens the little white gat

dialogues.speaker: AT THE DOOR,
dialogues.text: he rings the doorbell, afraid he might break something. A BLONDE HOUSEWIFE in tennis whites, obviously in a hurry opens the door -- only to be greeted by a BUCKETFUL OF SLOP thrown past her, onto her peach Oriental rug. She SCREAMS in horror, turns to challenge the perpetrator of this atrocity and, seeing Lurch, SCREAMS again. In a panic, she tries to slam the door on Lurch, but, lik the salesman's manual undoubtedly advised, he STICKS his foot in the way. The door partially RIPS off its hinges. Lurch steps inside and shuts the door as best he can. A moment passes. The door swings open and Lurch exits, jauntily waving a check.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morticia is telling a story to a group of TODDLERS, who have gathered in a circle around her, sitting on carpet squares. The room is sunny and cheerful, with crayon drawings taped to the walls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... and so the witch lured Hansel and Gretel into the candy house, by promising them more sweets. And she told them to look in the oven, and she was about to push them in, when, low and behold, Hansel pushed the poor, defenseless witch into the oven instead. Where she was burned alive, writhing in agony. Now, boys and girls, what do you think that feels like? After a beat, all the toddlers begin to CRY and WAIL.

dialogues.speaker: OMITTED
dialogues.text: thru 147

dialogues.speaker: OMITTED
dialogues.text: thru

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Granny holds a club behind her back as she stalks something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here kitty, kitty, kitty...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eating compulsively form a box of Mallomars, Gomez is still stretched out on the naked box springs. He stares vacantly at a game show on TV. "Jeopardy" is on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reading from the card)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Monsters Of History for $200. "He was known as the Butcher of Bavaria."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouts)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grandfather Addams! (smacks his forehead, hard)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damn! Not in the form of a question!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Granny, running now, club raised, hurries past the open window of the bungalow. She stops at the sight of Gomez inside, standing on the bed, staring at the television. C.U. on the TV set - Gomez is now watching Geraldo Rivera hosting his tabloid style show.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Voodoo zombies - the stuff of legend, or a living nightmare? Do zombies really exist? How are they made? Where can we find them? Call in with your comments.

dialogues.speaker: A154 CONTINUED
dialogues.text: A CALL-IN NUMBER is flashed on the screen.    Gomez reach for the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Abigail and Gordon are seated at opposite ends of the table, having lunch. It is very quiet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After lunch, we'll try again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (very flat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll find the money. And meanwhile, we have this little nest. Quiet and cozy. Without that dreadful family.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just the two of us, away from the world. Our dream come true.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Mother. As Fester repeats "Yes, Mother", in his drone, Abigail mimics him, silently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C.U. on the TV screen.   Geraldo is talking to a woman in the studio audience.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So your son was brainwashed by voodoo slave masters and forced to recruit others. Let's take a call.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on the studio PA system)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Geraldo...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cutting him off)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Addams, please stop calling. We don't know where they meet.

dialogues.speaker: A155 CONTINUED
dialogues.text: PULL BACK to the motel room. Gomez lets the phone drop. Morticia, seated on the edge of the box spring, tries to comfort him. Pugsley, Wednesday and Lurch are seated nearby, very worried about Gomez, as at a death watch. Gomez is now surrounded by junk food, and a mountain of junk food wrappers, bags and styrofoam containers. Ritually, as handmaidens, Morticia brings Gomez the remote control for the TV, and Wednesday brings him a copy of TV Guide. Pugsley brings Gomez a bag of "Doritos", and Lurch brings him a canister of "Pringles". Gomez uses the remote to switch channels.   An episode of "The Cosby Show" comes on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Re-run. He switches off the set and stares at the blank screen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't understand. All he does is watch TV and eat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know - Gomez, let's go for a drive. The whole family.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (not even turning)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A drive? And miss "Matlock"? Granny opens the door and sticks her head in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dinner's going to be late. She slams the door.   We hear her whistling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here, boy.   Here, boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morticia is putting Wednesday to bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If that man isn't Uncle Fester, then who is he, mother?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know, darling.   I wish I did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why is that lady doing all this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's hard to say. Sometimes people have had terrible childhoods. And sometimes they just haven't found their special place in life. And sometimes they're dogs from hell and must be destroyed. Morticia kisses Wednesday and she closes her eyes to go to sleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The family sleeps - all but Morticia. She sits up in bed beside Gomez. She looks around at her family. Wednesday sleeps in the same bed as Granny. Lurch is flat out on the floor. Pugsley uses him for a mattress, and Thing uses Pugsley. Pugsley snores the inhale part of a snore, Lurch groans the exhale part, and Thing punctuates by wiggling. Morticia stares down at Gomez - for a long beat. She strokes his hair lovingly. Full of resolve, she gets out of bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fester is lying in bed, the covers around his chin. Abigail sits on the bed beside him, tucking him in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know why you've been so glum. It's because it's taking us a little longer than we'd hoped to find the gold. Isn't that right? Fester turns away, depressed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course it is. Well, don't you worry - we're right on the verge. Tomorrow, for certain, my darling. (she kisses him on the forehead, and stands. She goes to the door, and turns)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, some people might think it's strange, for a mother and son to be so close. I think it's beautiful. Don't you, Gordon? Fester mumbles something, under his breath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (very stern)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (dutifully)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, mother. It's beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (instantly very sweet, dabbing her eye with a fingertip) Look - I'm weeping.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Abigail exits. The minute the door shuts, Fester gets out of bed. He is fully clothed. He goes to the window, and begins to climb out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morticia, fully dressed, wearing her cloak, heads off down the walk. Unseen by her, Thing trails after.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morticia, just outside Gate, struggles to get it open, Thing clutching the bars, also attempting to block her way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop it, you two.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morticia breaks free of Thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tully opens the front door. He smiles maliciously at the sight of Morticia on the stoop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I would like to speak with Fester.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tully steps aside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've been expecting you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morticia crosses the threshold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thing does his damnedest to flag down any of the few oncoming cars. He waves to no avail, DANCES AROUND in frustration, then tries HITCHHIKING, sticking out his thumb. A passing car splashes him with mud. Screwing up his courage, in a kamikaze leap, he GRABS ahold of the bumper of the next car that comes along and hangs on for dear life as the car SPEEDS down the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morticia is now stretched out on the torture RACK. Fester and Tully are securing her hands and feet, under Abigail' supervision. Fester seems torn, agitated, upset.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Abigail, graciously)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are a desperate woman, consumed by greed and infinite bitterness. (a beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We could have been such friends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think so. The vault, Mrs. Addams - any thoughts?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sweetly, to Abigail)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Despite everything, I don't hate you. I pity you. Persecution, fiendish torture, inhuman depravity - sometimes it's just not enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gordon - let's get started.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But, Mother...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop stalling!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not stalling! Stop badgering me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pushing Fester aside)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tully, take over! Tighten it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd love to, you know that, but - I've got this stomach thing. When I torture people. It's just me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shoving Tully toward the rack)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Morticia, politely)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's your bathroom?

dialogues.speaker: NOW
dialogues.text: Tully shuts his eyes and tightens the rack. Morticia's bones make a horrible POPPING, STRETCHING SOUND. She MOANS, rather sensually.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Again! Tully tightens the rack again. More BONE-POPPING NOISES. Morticia MOANS again, even more orgasmically.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tighter! Tully tightens the rack a third time. BONE-POPPING NOISES Morticia MOANS, very voluptuously. She opens her eyes. She sighs, in afterglow. She glances at Tully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Tully, flirtatiously)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've done this before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A hand possessed, Thing RACES up the driveway, raising dust as he goes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thing leaps dramatically onto the porch, then stops dead to knock on the cabin door. After a beat:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who is it?     We're paid through Thursday. He opens the door.    Thing rushes in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thing skitters on the kitchen counter, frantically signing. In the background, the rest of the family sleeps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispers)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Slow down, Thing! It's terrible when you stutter! Frustrated, Thing grabs a SPOON and begins tapping out MORSE CODE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morticia in danger... stop!    Send help at once ... stop! Thing flops down in exhausted triumph.    Gomez grabs him and heads off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morticia is now lashed to an ENORMOUS TORTURE WHEEL. Tully and Abigail are tending the stick BRANDING IRONS stuck in the roaring fire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Abigail)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't! Not with red-hot pokers!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (queasy)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is this gonna smell?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (graciously, with understanding)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tully Alford - charlatan. Deadbeat. Parasite. How Gomez adored you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, not enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morticia, please...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dear Fester - or whomever you are. Which is the real you - the loathsome, under-handed monster you've become? Or the loathsome, underhanded monster we came to love?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (desperately)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't ask me...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fester - I saw you tonight, at my window. I know it was you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (furious)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gordon?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (very upset)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was... restless! I couldn't sleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gordon, I have a thought. Just a notion, top of my head. Tell me what you think. Since you and Mrs. Addams are so very close... Abigail takes a red-hot POKER out of the fire and hands i to Fester.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... be my guest.

dialogues.speaker: OMITTED
dialogues.text: thru 164

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gomez cuts the engine. The car glides silently through Gate -- who opens uncharacteristically without a creak. Gomez stops the car and skulks out. Thing skulks after him. Gomez sees the reflections of the roaring fire through the study window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Fester takes the poker and approaches Morticia - GOMEZ CRASHES THROUGH THE WINDOW, in a back-flip. Thing JUDO-FLIPS in after Gomez.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cara mia!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mon cher!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Addams! Thing tosses Gomez a saber off the study wall. Tully also grabs a saber, and approaches Gomez from behin

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darling, take care! Without even looking, Gomez parries Tully's blow from behind. Then he whirls on Tully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dirty pool, old man.      Never again!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is for keeps, Gomez!      Not just doubloons! Tully feints, then slashes - shredding the front of Gomez jacket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One for you, Tully, and... Gomez ATTACKS - HIS BLADE FLASHING LIKE LIGHTNING. In a blur of action, Tully's sword is knocked from his hand an he's sent tumbling backwards, finally landing on his knee

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... one for me! Tully looks up at Gomez with cowardly, pleading eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gomez... it's Tully. I'm your lawyer. I'm on retainer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let him up! Gomez turns to see...

dialogues.speaker: ABIGAIL -
dialogues.text: who now has a pistol aimed at Morticia.       One shot an Morticia will die horribly. Gomez throws aside his sword.      Tully scrambles to his feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Gomez) That's right! Now get moving - Addams, take him to the vault. And if you're not back in one hour... (the pistol aimed at Morticia, and using her accent) I displace her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gomez is near enough now to take Morticia's hand, on the torture wheel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tish - seeing you like this.   My blood boils.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As does mine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (touching the torture wheel) This wheel of pain...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our wheel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CU on Fester, confused at watching this emotional display.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Morticia) To live without you - only that would be torture.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Gomez)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A day alone - only that would be death. Gomez kisses Morticia's hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Knock it off!    The vault, Addams - right now!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But, Mother can't we... Gomez reaches for the book that will open the secret panel:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can it, Gordon! Stop dragging your feet! You disgust me - you're nothing but a useless, snivelling baby! A stone around my neck! What was I thinking - I should've left you where I found you! At Abigail's final words, Fester suddenly LEAPS FORWARD.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No tricks, Gomez! That's the wrong book!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gomez's hand is on the right book, "Greed," but Fester stops him from pulling it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Allow me... Gomez looks into Fester's eyes -- realizing what he's about to do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (murmuring)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good show, old man... Fester reaches for a DIFFERENT BOOK -- "Hurricane Irene: Nightmare from Above." Seeing the title of the book, Tully suddenly panics:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Put that book down, Gordon! You don't know what it can do! It's not just literture!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (advancing on Tully)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, really?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm your friend, Gordon - think of the doubloons!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're not yours, Tully!     Back off! ANGLE on Gomez, releasing Morticia from the torture wheel

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quickly, my darling! He helps her down from the wheel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leather straps, red-hot pokers...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Later, my dearest. ANGLE on Fester, facing off with Abigail, as Tully cowers

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keep the book closed, Gordon - listen to mother!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll never listen to you - not ever again!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had to be strict with you - because I cared! Put it down!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You never really loved me! ANGLE on Gomez and Morticia, nearing the bookcase.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come, my love - to safety!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But what of Fester?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling out, to Fester)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Old man, this way! ANGLE on Abigail and Fester.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop whining, you little good- for-nothing! Be a man!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a terrible mother!   There, I said it! Fester opens the book, and blasts Tully out of the window Then he blasts Abigail out as well. ANGLE ON GOMEZ, who has now pulled the right book, "Greed to open the bookshelf. Amid the storm, he is leading Morticia behind the bookshelf. He tries to hold the bookshelf open for Fester to follow, fighting the gale force winds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling out to Fester)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Old man! This way! ANGLE ON THING, across the room, struggling across the floor toward the bookshelf. Thing fights the wind, which pelts him with papers and other flying debris. Gomez can no longer fight the storm, and the bookshelf slams shut. Fester desperately tries to close the book to quell the storm, but a HUGE BOLT OF LIGHTNING ZAPS HIM. He falls to the floor, with electricity coursing through him. MOVE IN on the storm raging within the pages of the book, then -

dialogues.speaker: OMITTED
dialogues.text: thru 169

dialogues.speaker: OMITTED
dialogues.text: thru 173

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A group of little CHILDREN approach the front door. There is a hand-lettered sign on the door reading "HALLOWEEN OPEN HOUSE." The children are dressed in traditional Halloween costumes - there's a witch, a ghost, a skeleton etc., and they all carry trick-or-treat bags. They giggle and chatter. One of the children is pushed forward, and he KNOCKS on the front door. As the door opens, the children CHANT:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trick or... They freeze in mid-chant. We do not see who has opened the door, but the children do. After a beat, they SCREAM IN HORROR and run, terrified, back toward the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lurch is closing the front door, looking puzzled. The family is busily decorating the house for their annua Halloween festivities. All the decorations are elegant yet ancient, dusty and faded. The crystal gloves in the chandeliers have been replaced by miniature jack o- lanterns. Skeletons, each wearing a top hat, hang from the sconces by the nooses around their necks. There are clusters of black and orange balloons, covered with cobwebs. Uncle Fester and Thing are draping the banisters and stairway railings with a garland made from crepe paper, dead branches and spanish moss. Skulls, each holding a candle, are scattered about, on the stairs and the furniture. A stuffed, life-size scarecrow leans against the stairway, with a pitchfork through its throat A banner on the wall reads "HAPPY HALLOWEEN", and the letters drip with blood. Gomez hangs upside down from the balcony.   Morticia hand him a decoration. Granny appears from the kitchen, carrying a tray of food.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, it's their loss. I even made finger sandwiches. Perched on Fester's shoulder, Thing shakes in fear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (petting Thing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, calm down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here we come! Wednesday and Pugsley come down the stairs. Wednesday is dressed in her usual style, but Pugsley is dressed as a tiny version of UNCLE FESTER, COMPLETE WITH BALD HEAD A GREATCOAT. The adults are delighted. Gomez flips down onto his feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pugsley, old man!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (delighted)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Uncle Fester)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you like it? Fester is very touched; he picks Pugsley up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What can I say? He's going to break hearts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's get a picture!     Lurch?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yes - in the den.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Everyone starts to move toward the den. There is a KNOCK on the door. Everyone turns. Lurch opens the door. Standing outside are Margaret and Cousin It. Margaret is dressed as a fairy princess, complete with wand. Cousin It wears a cowboy hat, a bandanna and a holster. Margaret is radiant, obviously very much in love.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trick or treat!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ooot oot glibber.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, everyone! We have guests!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Margaret. Cousin It - I almost didn't recognize you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Isn't he handsome? Everyone keeps asking where he bought his costume.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (admiringly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is a wonderful hat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Wednesday)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what are you, darling?   Where's your costume?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (solemnly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is my costume. I'm a homicidal maniac. They look just like everyone else.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fester and Pugsley are posed at one end of the room. Lurch has set up an easel and canvas; he is painting Fester and Pugsley's portrait. Gomez and Wednesday are sitting on the floor amid newspapers, carving a pumpkin. Morticia is knitting. Margaret and Cousin It sit together holding hands. Granny brings people cups of steaming punch, from a punch bowl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Halloween - it's such a special time. Ghosts and goblins. Witches on broomsticks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Children begging in the streets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm so glad I can share this night with my family - my real family. Now that I've got my memory back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That unfortunate woman. Filled with evil. (shaking her head, sadly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But not enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Fester)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She wasn't your mother.     She just said that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ooot oot gleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to It)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You remember, old sport - she really did find him tangled in a tuna net, twenty-five years ago. With amnesia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From the Bermuda Triangle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ooot oot oot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How true.   Stranger things have happened.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, and I'm not bitter, but I blame Tully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ooot blipper gleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (the coquette)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, stop. I'm blushing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Fester)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank God for that lightning. Knocked some sense into you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, Uncle Fester?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (jovially)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pugsley...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For the picture? Fester pops a light bulb into his mouth.   It lights. Pugsley giggles. Gomez stands up, having finished the pumpkin. He places it on a table, and lights the candle inside. The pumpkin glows. It has ONE EYE IN THE MIDDLE OF ITS FOREHEAD. Everyone oohs and ahhs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, all the old sayings are true. There's no place like home. And blood is thicker than water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And just as refreshing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, everybody - time for a game! What shall it be - bobbing for apples?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charades?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ooot glibber glip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course - "Wake The Dead."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (delighted, to Gomez remembering this childhood favorite)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Wake The Dead"!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (equally excited)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Wake The Dead"! Out to the cemetery! Come on, everyone! Everyone starts to exit, chattering happily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Granny)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've never played this before - how does it go?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you bring a shovel?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uncle Fester, will you be on my team?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, mine!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Wednesday)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I tell you what - we'll give you a head start. Three skulls and a pelvis - how's that? Pugsley and Wednesday cheer and run out.   Fester faces Gomez.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My own dear brother - who could be more precious?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blood is thicker than water, old man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (touched by the brothers devotion)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And just as refreshing. Gomez offers his hand.   Fester takes it, in a manly handshake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let us never be parted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let us always be as one. Fester flips Gomez in a JUDO FLIP. Gomez LANDS - At the foot of a glass display case. The camera pans up the case. It contains ABIGAIL AND TULLY, EXPERTLY MOUNTED AND STUFFED. Fester rises, dusting himself off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (joyfully, to Gomez and Morticia)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll catch up. Fester runs out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone is gone. Morticia and Gomez have drifted into the front hall; they are moving toward the front door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (deeply satisfied)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our family... what are they?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Tish - what a night. Everyone -- together at last. What more could we ask?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gomez? Morticia holds up the garment she's been knitting - it's a BABY JUMPER WITH THREE LEGS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (ecstatic)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cara mia... is it true?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shaking her head "yes")

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oui, mon cher... They embrace, as the front door SWINGS OPEN, of its own accord.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morticia and Gomez are silhouetted in the doorway. There is a FULL MOON. In the distance, a wolf HOWLS. Wispy GHOSTS flit through the night sky. A human SCREAM is heard, followed by Granny's CACKLE. In the cemetery, torches are seen, like fireflies.
